## Hello

About Me

# Techniques

#### Techniques used will be defined by what you need from the session. This
is what I am trained in:

Sports Massage

###### Train, recover, perform

As sports people we tend to push our bodies hard, short-changing it on
recovery and sleep in the quest of balancing work, life and sport. Keeping you
on top of your training plan is our goal.

##### Postural Assessment

###### Observe, identify, implement

Imbalances in load through the muscles and joints often result in injuries or
pain, especially when doing repetitive movements, such as running or cycling.
By observing your posture, identifying the fascia or muscles affecting your
posture and then implementing my strategy to correct this pattern, allows me
to identify what may be causing an injury.

##### Therapeutic Massage

###### Relieve, resolve, restore

As we slowly lose our battle against gravity, changes in our posture result in
the body's inability to heal a problem. Therapeutic massage aims to fix
issues, so you don't need to live with them.

##### Kinesio  
Taping

###### Clever, magical, helpful

First patented in 1967, Kinesio Tape works on the fascial system underneath
the skin. Neuro sensors in the fascia send information to the brain related to
load, by applying Kinesio tape in different ways, a change in the information
sent to the brain can get a muscle to activate more strongly or with lower
power, or it can be used to reduce pain in the area.

##### Myofascial Release

###### Evaluate, align, systemic

Myofascial Release treats the body as an integrated unit. Load runs along
fascial lines, with tension in one part affecting the body in another part,
usually causing pain. Treating the myofascial system takes an integrated look
at the body and aims to rebalance load through the correct fascial lines.

##### Muscle

##### testing

###### Test, comparison, advise

Understanding the symmetry between both sides of the body and identifying
where some muscle may not be boing their work, enables me to give exercises to
kick-start these muscles so they can pick up the workload from the ones
overworking and complaining (usually the ones in pain).
